none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from E. B. Cushing, April 2, 1891
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from E. B. Cushing, April 2, 1891
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 6 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Margin: I think you Could get Cols agree to any petition among the boys. When Foster goes on the Commission his place will be vacant]

(G. H.) M. 18½.
GALVESTON, HARRISBURG & SAN ANTONIO RAILWAY CO.
TEXAS & NEW ORLEANS RAILROAD CO.

To
Subject

Office of

Lozier Pecos Co Tx April 2d 1891

My dear Sir:
Your letter 29th inst was forwarded to
me here - I have written to night to have the
petition started in Houston – Will write to
the boys elsewhere also tomorrow – I will be
in Houston in about a week when I will give
the matter personal attention and rush it all
I can – I have mentioned the matter to several
of the boys and they have all seemed willing to
sign the paper and all express hope that
you may be appointed tho several thought
it useless to proceed as you likely would
not accept the appointment – I told them that
you would very likely accept if offered to
you on a/c of your interest in the School
Walter Moore would qualify his signature
"Provided Mr McInnis will agree not to make
war on Gov. Ross" – I told him I should ask
you no questions even if I failed to get his influence
Strange how silly some men can be with a head full
of brains. Speaking to a gentleman of the
idea he said he would sign the petition and
get Col Hutchenson to do so hence I will have
him get up a "letter" to the Gov & have a
few leading men in Ho sign it – Will rush the mat
ter as I can get back – Sorry I have to be absent now

Yours Truly
E B Cushing

To L. L. McInnis Esq.

**A Deep Dive into Transcription: From Image to Text**

Okay, here's the deal: I'm staring at this image, and I need to get this right.  My immediate task is clear: transcribing this handwritten letter. But I'm not just typing – I'm thinking, analyzing, and interpreting every stroke.

First, I need to understand the framework. I am a professional transcriptionist, which means accuracy is paramount, and I need to handle all these HTML tags properly. This means the structure and readability must be perfect. I need to make sure I get the headers, footers, and margins labeled properly, too.

I begin by analyzing the image itself. I can see this is a handwritten letter on company stationery. I see the header "M. 18 1/2". I see "Lozier Pecos Co Tx April 2d 1891". The handwriting looks a bit rushed, but it is readable. I note the salutation, "My dear Sir," and the bottom-left addressee, "To L. L. McInnis Esq."

Now, I start to transcribe, line by line, remembering to use the specified HTML tags. I must also interpret the faint ink spots. At the top of the page, written upside down, is some marginal text.  I need to figure out what that says. After rotating the text in my head, I read "I think you could get..." The next word is unclear.

I carefully transcribe the printed header and the dateline. Then I move into the body of the letter.

I am transcribing this sentence by sentence, and correcting my own reading.

There are names involved, like "Walter Moore", "Gov Ross", and "Col Hutchenson." There's also the mention of a "School" and a "petition," plus references to "Houston."  I'm reading closely and making sure I do not misinterpret any letters.

As I go, I'm already refining the transcription. I'm using HTML tags for formatting. I'm using the `<sup>` tag where needed, such as with "2d" and "29th." I check the spelling, looking out for abbreviations like "inst" and "a/c." I will make sure the text follows all the instructions I was given.

I now need to make certain I get the upside-down text correct. I read the letters, one at a time, and go back and re-read them.

The upside-down text looks like:  "I think you could get [?] agree to any petition among the boys." The [?] word begins with a C, but the handwriting is strange. It could be "Cols," implying "Colonels," which fits with the other references. Or maybe it is "Couls?" I will carefully read the handwritten text to be certain. After repeated checks, and because I see an association with the title "Col" (Colonel), I'm going to put `Cols`.

After reading through the whole text, I start the final editing, and make adjustments. The word at the end of the text is slightly unclear. I will re-read and edit and adjust. I must accurately capture the handwriting. I decide to keep `ter`, even though it looks scribbled. I am sure I must include that scrawled part of the word, as the word "soon" is also implied.

Now, all I need to do is format it all using the proper tags and send.  The text should be perfect.
